conclusion: Determine the time t for the conductor rod to slide down a distance x until it reaches its maximum speed vm.
When the conductor rod reaches its maximum speed, the forces acting on it balance each other.
The gravitational force component along the incline is balanced by the magnetic force induced by the current due to the motion of the rod.
The gravitational force component along the incline is mg sin theta.
The magnetic force (Lorentz force) is given by FB = BIL, where I is the current induced in the rod.
The induced emf in the rod is E = BLvm.
The current I in the circuit is I = E/(R + r) = BLvm/(R + r).
The magnetic force is FB = B(BLv_m/(R + r))L = B^2L^2v_m/(R + r).
At maximum speed, the forces balance: mg sin theta = B^2L^2v_m/(R + r).
Solving for vm gives vm = mg sin theta (R + r)/(B^2L^2).
Before reaching the maximum speed, the rod accelerates under the net force.
The equation of motion is ma = mg sin theta - B^2L^2v/(R + r).
The acceleration a is a = dv/dt.
The differential equation becomes m dv/dt = mg sin theta - B^2L^2v/(R + r).
Rearrange to dv/dt = g sin theta - B^2L^2v/(m(R + r)).
This is a first-order linear differential equation.
We can solve it using separation of variables or integrating factor methods.
Here, we use the integrating factor method.
Let k = B^2L^2/(m(R + r)). The equation becomes dv/dt + kv = g sin theta.
The integrating factor is e^(kt).
Multiply both sides by the integrating factor: e^(kt) dv/dt + ke^(kt) v = g sin theta e^(kt).
